title.narrative: Capacity for Governance Programme & Conflict Management

description.narrative: Supporting Nigeria's Capacity for Governance and Conflict Prevention, Management and Peace-Building at the Federal and State level.
Support to deepening democracy in Nigeria including the 2011 elections
independent political entity
Elections - elections

1. Extent to which Credible, Transparent and Sustainable Electoral Processes has been established. 2. Extent to which there is an Improvement in the Democratic Quality of Political Engagement. 3. Extent to which there is an enhancement of the participation by Women, Youth and other marginalized groups 4. Extent to which Channels of Civic Engagement has been strengthened.

comment.narrative: 1. Partially - Credible, Transparent and Sustainable Electoral Process yet to be mainstreamed. 2. Partially - Quality of Political Engagement needs to meet the standard set in the 2012-2016 Strategic Programme of Action. 3. Partially - The Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC) Gender Policy is yet to be developed 4. Partially - Relatively low levels of civic awareness of and engagement with government and elections at local and State levels.

1. Increased communication and cooperation between INEC, political parties, CSOs and key stakeholders to improve public approval of electoral operations and contribute to peaceful elections. 2. Electoral procedures, and voter education materials are appropriate to women, youths and PWDs 3. Civil Society Organizations (CSOs) are proactively and constructively engaged in informing and monitoring the electoral process in the lead up to the 2015 elections. 4. Monitor and report the experiences of women during elections to address violence and ensure peaceful elections where women participate freely

1. The Abuja Accord on peaceful election was signed by key political parties and presidential candidates. 2. Nigeria held its widely acclaimed, free, credible and peaceful elections. 3. The Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC) instituted the National Interagency Committee on Voter Education and Publicity (NICVEP) which ensured that electoral procedures, and voter education materials were appropriate to women, youths and other marginalized groups. 4. A Women Situation room was established in collaboration with UNWOMEN at the national and 10 state levels which monitored the election and reported incidents of violence against women. The commitments secured from the political parties, youth and the media contributed to the reduced violence incidents while the rapid response mechanism in place addressed issues of violence.

title.narrative: EU ADDL SUPPT TO ELECTORAL CYC

description.narrative: EU ADDITIONAL SUPPORT TO NIGERIA ELECTORAL CYCLE 2011 - 2015
Elections - elections

1. Extent to which the Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC) performance benchmarks achieved within set timelines. 2. Independent National Electoral Commission’s level of information sharing with stakeholder.

comment.narrative: 1. Partially - the Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC) launched its Strategic Programme of Action 2012-2016 with performance benchmarks in June 2013 2. Partially - During the previous electoral cycles, there were no deliberate efforts to share the observation reports beyond the press conference and the lodgment of the reports with the Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC).

1. Conduct extensive voter education campaigns with a focus on youth, women and peaceful elections covering all the states of the Federation 2. Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC) to set up and run an Election Management System for effective and efficient operation and coordination of crucial aspects of election administration and management for the 2015 general elections. 3. Build capacity of the Election Petition Tribunals developed with a view to fast- track adjudication of election petitions and address issues of inconsistent judgements.

1. Achieved: Comprehensive voter education campaigns were delivered in all the 774 Local Government Areas of the Federation through both traditional and nontraditional mechanisms which contributed to increased voter turnout and reduced invalid votes. 2. Partially Achieved: INEC significantly improved on the 2015 electoral process with the automation of many electoral processes, including the deployment and retrieval of electoral materials and personnel and the development of manuals for the efficient operationalization of the appropriate channels of communication and electoral support infrastructure. 3. Achieved: The Election Petition Tribunals had managed to fast- track the election adjudication process with no reported case of election petition lapses and inconsistent judgements

title.narrative: Capacity Development Project for Successful CPAP Impleme

description.narrative: The project is designed to provide capacity development support to CPAP implementing partners that is unlikely to be properly addressed and funded.
A Capacity Building project to help jump-start the implementation of the Country Programme Action Plan (CPAP) in 13 of the 36 States of Nigeria.
seat of a first-order administrative division
Accountability - local government finance
Responsiveness to requests, speed of response, quality of advisory services

comment.narrative: Numerous national planning frameworks, complex coordination structure, considerable gap between federation and states, high programmatic and financial risk for the UN, significant programmatic volatility
No implementation. Project operational closed
No implementation. Project operational closed

title.narrative: 4221: Less Burnt for A Clean Earth (FSP)

description.narrative: Project’s incremental strategy is to organize and bring the informal waste sector into the formal waste management to achieve reduction in UPOPs emissions from two sources: open burning of collected waste and open burning of uncollected waste.

title.narrative: Less Burnt for A Clean Earth AWP_2013
Less Burnt for A Clean Earth AWP_2012
Less Burnt for A Clean Earth
Less Burnt for A Clean Earth

description.narrative: Pilot programme on the management and elimination of Persistent Organic Pollutants from agricultural and waste burning in Nigeria
independent political entity
Energy - policy, planning and administration
Extent of reduction of atmospheric release of Unintentional Persistent Organic Pollutants (UPOPs) from municipal waste in two states.

comment.narrative: Open source burning of Municipal and Agricultural Waste accounts for an annual emission of 574 g I-TEQ/a in Kano and Anambra States

1. Reduction of emissions to a level of 300g I-TEQ/a 2. Reduction of Unintentional Persistent Organic Pollutants (UPOPs) released from open burning 3. Training of environmental laws enforcement officers from the pilot states on enforcement of environmental regulations on municipal waste management and Unintentional Persistent Organic Pollutants (UPOPs) reduction in Nigeria. 4. Cultivation of 500 ha of farmland without burning 5. Completion of summer internship programme for university students 6. Creation of project e-library

1. Achieved - Emissions reduced to 274g I-TEQ/a in 2015 2. Achieved - 60 environmental laws enforcement officers from the pilot states and the federal level trained on enforcement of environmental regulations for municipal waste management. 3. Largely achieved - 469 ha of farmland (by 347 local farmers) were cultivated without burning 4. Achieved - summer internship programme for university students completed. 5. Not achieved - project e-library yet to be created.

description.narrative: Programme for Territorial Approach to Climate Change: Towards Low Carbon and Climate Resilient Development in Delta State, Nigeria

title.narrative: Prodoc on Territorial Approach to Climate Chnage in Delta State, Nigeria

description.narrative: Territorial Approach to Climate Change (TACC) focusing on Delta State South-South, Nigeria.
populated place

1. Extent to which biophysical and socio-economic assessment of environmental degradation and climate change have been conducted in Delta State. 2. Extent to which plans for Green House Gas (GHG) mitigation and adaptation investments have been developed in Delta State public and private sectors. 3. Extent to which Green House Gas (GHG) mitigation and adaptation interventions have been piloted in communities most vulnerable to climate change impacts. 4. Extent to which best practices for development of Green House Gas (GHG) mitigation and adaptation investments have been disseminated to national government and to local authorities in other states within the Niger Delta.

comment.narrative: 1. Not adequate – A comprehensive Biophysical and socio-economic assessment of environmental degradation and climate change has not been conducted in Delta State. 2. Not adequate – Plans for Green House Gas (GHG) mitigation and adaptation investments is yet to be developed in Delta State public and private sectors. 3. Not adequate – Green House Gas (GHG) mitigation and adaptation interventions have not been piloted in communities most vulnerable to climate change impacts. 4. Not adequate – best practices for development of Green House Gas (GHG) mitigation and adaptation investments have not been disseminated to national government and to local authorities in other states within the Niger Delta.
Operationally Closed
Operationally Closed

description.narrative: Mainstream biodiversity development priorities into O&G Sector policies and operations using the governance framework of law, policy, and institutional capacity and also the Niger Delta Biodiversity Trust as a development mechanism for local communities.

The objective of the project is aimed towards mainstreaming of biodiversity management priorities into the oil and gas sector development policies and operations especially in the Niger Delta communities
independent political entity
Energy - policy, planning and administration

1. Extent to which governance framework of law, policy, and institutional capacity to enable the mainstreaming of biodiversity management into the O&G sector in the Niger Delta is strengthened. 2. Extent to which Government, the O&G industry and local communities build and pilot new biodiversity action planning tools for the proactive biodiversity management in the Niger Delta. 3. Extent to which stakeholders support long-term biodiversity management in the Niger Delta by capitalizing and accessing the Niger Delta Biodiversity Trust as a collaborative engagement mechanism for local communities, O&G companies and Government.

comment.narrative: 1. Not adequate – there is weak governance framework of law, policy, and institutional capacity to enable the mainstreaming of biodiversity management into the O&G sector in the Niger Delta is strengthened. 2. Not adequate - Government, the O&G industry and local communities are yet to build and pilot new biodiversity action planning tools for the proactive biodiversity management in the Niger Delta. 3. Not adequate - A Niger Delta Biodiversity Trust as a collaborative engagement mechanism for local communities, O&G companies and Government does not exist.

1. Review of Policy document on the Oil and Gas industry. 2. Status of the barrier islands surveyed and documented. 3. Short courses mainstreamed into curriculum of training institutions in the Niger Delta.
1. Barrier islands surveyed and endangered species documented and mapped out. 2. Short courses developed but yet to be mainstreamed into the curriculum of training institutes in the Niger Delta

description.narrative: To mainstream biodiversity management priorities into the Niger Delta oil and gas (O&G) sector development policies and operations.
Direct: Improved management of 600 km2) â€œinside the fenceâ€? of O&G operations as measured by adoption of Biodiversity Action Plans for a target number of O&G operations in the Delta.

comment.narrative:
SPDC has carried out BAPs in the following states:
Akwa Ibom (1),
Stubbs Creek Forest Reserve. SPDC has no footprints in this tract, but it still carried out the BAP. the O&G company working in the area, ExxonMobil has not cooperated with SPDC or this project to consider further investments in the Forest Reserve. The situation has further been complicated by new Oil Mineral Licenses (OML) leases in the area.
Bayelsa state
BAP development in Bayelsa has focussed on the Gbaran-Ubie integrated oil and gas project. The following Forest Reserves have been the subject of BAP in bayelsa: a) Apoi Creek Forest Reserve, b) Nun River Forest Reserve, c) Taylor Creek Forest Reserve? (straddling Bayelsa and Rivers states), d) Edumanom, e) Egbedi and f) Ikebiri Forest Reserves. SPDC has not signed off on these recently conducted BAPs.
Rivers state (2)
Upper Orashi Forest Reserve
Taylor Creek Forest Reserve (straddliding)?
?
At least 600 km2 of O&G footprint covered by new or revised BAP for O&G operations in ND.
A combined figure of 80608 hectares has been subject of BAP in three states-Akwa Ibom, Bayelsa and Rivers state.

description.narrative:
Indirect: Threats to biodiversity linked to O&G are reduced in a spatial area of 46,420 km2 as measured by condition, number or extent of key species and ecosystems in the Niger Delta:
- Area in ND where Niger Delta red colobus monkey is confirmed
- # of hectares of mangrove ecosystem in under improved special management regime
- # of hectares cover of barrier island lowland forest under protection.

comment.narrative:
- Area in ND where Niger Delta red colobus monkey is unknown and un-measured.
- Zero hectares of mangrove ecosystem in under improved special management regime
- Zero hectares cover of barrier island lowland forest under protection.

- Red colobus monkey is confirmed present in 15,000 hectares by end of project (EoP).
- At least 25,000 ha of mangrove ecosystem in under improved special management regime
- At least 10,000 ha cover of barrier island lowland forest under protection.

description.narrative: # of O&G companies and Government agencies utilizing IBAT regularly for Niger Delta biodiversity mainstreaming.

comment.narrative: Zero
At least three O&G companies and 3 Government agencies by end of project.

description.narrative: # of hectares of community PA/set-aside or other PA gazetted and under biodiversity management in four pilot States of the Niger Delta.

comment.narrative: Zero
At least 5,000 hectares by end of project.

description.narrative:
Amount of funding committed to the NDBT by EoP.
Presence or absence of operational Niger Delta Biodiversity Trust mechanism and level of funding committed.

comment.narrative:
Zero funding committed.
Does not exist. No funding committed to any mechanism for Delta biodiversity conservation/ mainstreaming

US$3 million committed to the Trust by EoP.
Niger Delta Biodiversity Trust (NDBT) Articles of Incorporation agreed upon by the GoN, O&G companies, and relevant civil society partners and legally approved under Nigeriaâ€™s Companies and Allied Matters Act.

description.narrative: # of primary laws and policies and regulations improved with biodiversity mainstreaming guidelines, recommendations, and amendments.

comment.narrative: No laws/ policies have biodiversity mainstreamed into them, including the EIA, EGASPIN, PIB, and Oil Spill Response Plan.
At least four have biodiversity mainstreamed into their language via adopted guidelines, amendments, or modified language in the laws themselves.

description.narrative: The governance framework of law, policy, and institutional capacity to enable the mainstreaming of biodiversity management into the O&G sector in the Niger Delta is strengthened.
# of central O&G policies and guidelines and plans that incorporate biodiversity management checklists, criteria and objectives

comment.narrative: Zero
At least three by end of project.
Working groups were created and most of the Oil and Gas Policies and guidelines can be said to be 60% completed. Reports are at draft stage. To be concluded by end of 2015.

description.narrative: Improvement in Score of UNDP Capacity Assessment Tool over life of project. (see PRODOC Annex 1)

comment.narrative: 5 out of 48, i.e.
Improvement from 5/45 to minimum 10/48.
Assessment not yet carried out as at the time of reporting.

description.narrative: # of measureable/ tangible improvements in the EIA process for biodiversity mainstreaming.

comment.narrative: EIA has few if any specific biodiversity conservation targets/ objectives.

Biodiversity mainstreamed into EIA process in at least 3 entry points.
(See PRODOC Matrix 1 under the description of output 1.3)
The process of mainstreaming is dependent on the activities being done by the Working Group which is yet to be completed. This would most likely be moved into 2016.

description.narrative: Level of improvement of data available through IBAT decision support tool.

comment.narrative: Info on KBA available through IBAT driven by one taxa (birds).
Coverage of taxonomic groups expanded to at least four in total.

description.narrative: Government, the O&G industry and local communities build and pilot new biodiversity action planning tools for the proactive biodiversity management in the Niger Delta.
Change in level of corporate investment in biodiversity management.

comment.narrative: TBD at project inception.
A 20% increase in corporate investment of O&G companies in biodiversity management will ensure biodiversity safeguarding at O&G extraction sites, pipeline and tanker transportation.

SPDC is maintaining some level of investments in its corporate biodiversity portfolio. But this has dwindled in the last three years. Serious consideation is still given to biodiversity in all development projects. Fall in global oil pices and divestment policies have been implicated in scaling down of biodiversity related activities.

description.narrative: # of O&G companies adopting new BAP for operations.

comment.narrative: Zero
At least 3 companies adopt model BAP for their inside the fence operations.
SPDC has adopted BAP as an integral part of its environment policy,.

description.narrative: Stakeholders support long-term biodiversity management in the Niger Delta by capitalizing and accessing the Niger Delta Biodiversity Trust as a collaborative engagement mechanism for local communities, O&G companies and Government at its core.
Presence/absence of NDB Trust operational and funded with a first tranche of US$ 3 million supporting biodiversity conservation in critical ecosystems within the whole of the Niger Delta Region

comment.narrative: No NDBT and minimal funding for biodiversity in general.
Niger Delta Biodiversity Trust operational with at least US$3 million in funding supporting biodiversity conservation in critical ecosystems within the whole of the Niger Delta Region
Draft Niger Delta Trust Fund prepared. Prospectus for investors prepared. Consultations with stakeholders to commence.

description.narrative: # of community proposed biodiversity conservation projects funded and operational in the four pilot States of the Niger Delta.

comment.narrative: Zero
At least 15 by end of project.
None has been achieved as at the time of reporting. Consultations have began with the relevant authorities in the four focus states for 2016

1. Established a Centre of excellence & learning on REDD+ in Cross River State 2. Design of a financing mechanism on Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and forest Degradation (REDD+) 3. description.narrative: 1. Number of Civil Society Organizations (CSOs) trained by the project in networking, partnership- building, project planning, implementation and reporting in relation to anti-corruption interventions. 2. comment.narrative: 1. 0 – Civil Society Organizations (CSOs) have limited capacity to articulate and aggregate their interest and engage in advocacy on Government’s anti-corruption interventions 2. 0 – No Civil Society Organization (CSO) is currently benefitting from CSO Anti-Corruption Grant scheme.

1. Organize/support two CSO Advisory Committee Meetings 2. Customized project management and thematic anti-corruption trainings for CSOs 3. Provide capacity-building and work towards enabling the grants scheme & design an award grant scheme. 4. Support meetings of 3 anti-corruption networks 5. Production of anti-corruption Outreach materials

1. Largely achieved- Two meetings of CSO Advisory Committee provided strategic guidance and approved the Workplans for the implementation of the Project. 2. Largely Achieved- CSOs partnership-building Workshops enhanced CSO access to ACAs 3. Largely Achieved- CSOs capacitated to offer top-notch application for, and implementation of Project and Grants. 4. Largely Achieved- CSO Networks articulated and aggregated their Agenda within a coordinated framework with the Presidential Advisory Committee on Anti-Corruption. 5. Largely Achieved- Dissemination of Documentary on Corruption enhanced awareness among CSOs.

Achieved- Training of personnel enhanced beneficiaries’ knowledge on civilian protection and camp management 5. Achieved- commemorative activities enhance awareness of peacebuilding among stakeholders.

title.narrative: ENHANCED POLICY & HR FOR HIV R

description.narrative: Enabling Policy and Human Rights Environment

Number of States where the National Plan of Action on GBV/HIV Intersections is operationalized 3. Number of States with Gender and Human Rights Technical Working Group (TWG) established

comment.narrative: 1. 0 – No Legal Environment Assessment conducted to provide evidence base for advocacy for legal and policy reforms 2. 0 – There is no states where the National Plan of Action on GBV/HIV Intersections is operationalized 3. 0 – There is no state with Gender and Human Rights Technical Working Group (TWG) established

1. Conduct Legal Environment Assessment (LEA) for HIV response in Nigeria 2. Conduct State level capacity building on Gender Based Violence/HIV intersections in Kogi, Niger 3. Establish and strengthen Gender and Human Rights Technical Working Group for HIV at National and State levels (Niger and Kogi)

1. Achieved - Legal Environment Assessment (LEA) validated 2. Largely achieved - State level implementation of the National Plan of Action on Gender Based Violence (GBV)/HIV intersections conducted raising awareness and action plan developed in three States of Niger, Kogi & Anambra 3. Achieved - HIV/AIDS Anti-stigma & Discrimination Bill validated in three States of Niger, Kogi & Anambra. 4. Achieved - Gender and Human Rights Technical Working Group established in Niger and Kogi States

description.narrative: Strengthening national capacities to attain strong, diversified, sustainable and equitable economc growth.
Major objectives of the project is to support the national Government in its processes of development planning and aid co-ordination.

1. Development of new Medium Term Development Plans (MTDP) in 2 States and Review of MTDP in one State. 2. Completion of GDP computation in 3 States. 3. Convene sub-national aid coordination meeting. 4. Production of 2015 development cooperation report at the national and in 2 States

1. Review of MTDP was completed in one State, while two State commenced the development of new MTDP 2. GDP computation was complete in one State 3. The 2015 Development Cooperation Report was completed at the National level and in one State 4. The Sub-national Aid Coordination Platform meeting was successfully convened.

1. Undertake 1 (one) Mid-year and End year project review meetings with Implementing Partners 2. Conduct 4 quarterly HACT spot-checks 3. Conduct 4 quarterly Monitoring Field Trips 4. Produce 2014 Country Office Annual Report

1. Partially achieved - 1 (one) Mid-year and End year project review meetings with Implementing Partners 2. Partially achieved - Two quarterly HACT spot-checks conducted 3. No quarterly Monitoring Field Trip conducted 4. 2014 Country Office Annual Report produced

description.narrative: EU Support to ECOWAS Regional Peace, Security and Stability Mandate
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1. Availability of a dedicated communication strategy aimed at addressing awareness of Small Arms and Light Weapons (SALW) 2. Extent to which training programmes have been organized for community level Civil Society organizations. 3. Number of Arms collection centres established 4. Number of community initiatives (projects) identified and implemented as a result of the arms collection exercise (collective and individual).

comment.narrative: 1. A communication strategy dedicated to addressing awareness of SALW in the selected regions is non-existent. 2. A number of training programmes have been organized in the past but not aimed at targeted beneficiaries. 3. No official record of small arms collection centres in targeted communities. 4. No official record of community based action plans and projects linked to small arms collection

1. Develop a communication strategy for an effective Small Arms and Light Weapons (SALW) intervention 2. Implement at least 3 targeted sensitization and awareness campaigns based on communication strategy. 3. Training of Civil Society Organizations on resource mobilization, partnerships building, management and gender related issues. 4. Identification of arms collection centres 5. Conduct a needs assessment of community based micro projects for beneficiary communities

1. Achieved - A communication strategy for Small Arms and Light Weapons (SALW) developed. 2. Largely achieved - sensitization and awareness campaigns in Nigeria's six geo-political zones was carried out. 3. Largely achieved - training took place in Akwa Ibom, Enugu and Sokoto. 4. Not achieved - Activity yet to be carried out. 5. Not achieved - needs assessment of community based micro projects yet to be done

1. Develop a communication strategy for an effective Small Arms and Light Weapons (SALW) intervention 2. Implement at least 3 targeted sensitization and awareness campaigns based on communication strategy. 3. Training of Civil Society Organizations on resource mobilization, partnerships building, management and gender related issues. 4. Identification of arms collection centres 5. Conduct a needs assessment of community based micro projects for beneficiary communities

1. Achieved - A communication strategy for Small Arms and Light Weapons (SALW) developed. 2. Largely achieved - radio sensitization and awareness raising campaigns were conducted in four targeted districts (Kenema, Kailahun, Kono and Koinadugu). This was followed by twelve (12) community sensitizations were conducted in twelve chiefdoms. 3. Partially achieved - 4. Achieved - 12 arms collection centres identified 5. description.narrative: EU Support to ECOWAS Regional Peace, Security and Stability Mandate
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1. Availability of a dedicated communication strategy aimed at addressing awareness of Small Arms and Light Weapons (SALW) 2. Extent to which training programmes have been organized for community level Civil Society organizations. 3. Number of Arms collection centres established 4. Number of community initiatives (projects) identified and implemented as a result of the arms collection exercise (collective and individual).

comment.narrative: 1. A communication strategy dedicated to addressing awareness of SALW in the selected regions is non-existent. 2. A number of training programmes have been organized in the past but not aimed at targeted beneficiaries. 3. No official record of small arms collection centres in targeted communities. 4. No official record of community based action plans and projects linked to small arms collection

1. Develop a communication strategy for an effective Small Arms and Light Weapons (SALW) intervention 2. Implement at least 3 targeted sensitization and awareness campaigns based on communication strategy. 3. Training of Civil Society Organizations on resource mobilization, partnerships building, management and gender related issues. 4. Identification of arms collection centers 5. Conduct a needs assessment of community based micro projects for beneficiary communities

1. Achieved - A communication strategy for Small Arms and Light Weapons (SALW) developed. 2. Largely achieved - sensitization and awareness campaigns carried out. This included six (6) town hall meetings were respectively held in Kablarken and Gedetarbo communities (Maryland County), and Glarro-Freetown and Parken Communities (River Gee County), Toe Town and Tiama Town (Grand Gedeh County). 3. Largely achieved - 18 participants (9 women - 9 men) from south-eastern counties of Grand Gedeh, River-Gee and Maryland were trained. 4. Achieved - 3 arms collection centres identified 5. Partially achieved - Needs Assessment conducted in three (3) communities in two (2) project intervention regions namely Maryland and River Gee counties

description.narrative: EU Support to ECOWAS Regional Peace, Security and Stability Mandate
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1. Availability of a dedicated communication strategy aimed at addressing awareness of Small Arms and Light Weapons (SALW) 2. Extent to which training programmes have been organized for community level Civil Society organizations. 3. Number of Arms collection centres established 4. Number of community initiatives (projects) identified and implemented as a result of the arms collection exercise (collective and individual).

comment.narrative: 1. A communication strategy dedicated to addressing awareness of SALW in the selected regions is non-existent. 2. A number of training programmes have been organized in the past but not aimed at targeted beneficiaries. 3. No official record of small arms collection centres in targeted communities. 4. No official record of community based action plans and projects linked to small arms collection

1. Develop a communication strategy for an effective Small Arms and Light Weapons (SALW) intervention 2. Implement at least 3 targeted sensitization and awareness campaigns based on communication strategy. 3. Training of Civil Society Organizations on resource mobilization, partnerships building, management and gender related issues. 4. Identification of arms collection centres 5. Conduct a needs assessment of community based micro projects for beneficiary communities

1. Achieved - An existing communication strategy for Small Arms and Light Weapons (SALW) was updated taking into account the vision of the project. 2. Largely achieved - sensitization and awareness campaigns was carried out as well as a community outreach initiative to work with the respective Mayors of the targeted communities. 3. Largely achieved - 30 participants from the target communities benefitted from the training. 4. Achieved - 6 arms collection centres identified. 5. Largely achieved - Needs Assessment conducted in the six (6) project intervention regions namely Abala, Banibangou, Inates, Gorooul, Tilia, and Tchintabaraden.

description.narrative: EU Support to ECOWAS Regional Peace, Security and Stability Mandate
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1. Availability of a dedicated communication strategy aimed at addressing awareness of Small Arms and Light Weapons (SALW) 2. Extent to which training programmes have been organized for community level Civil Society organizations. 3. Number of Arms collection centres established 4. Number of community initiatives (projects) identified and implemented as a result of the arms collection exercise (collective and individual).

comment.narrative: 1. A communication strategy dedicated to addressing awareness of SALW in the selected regions is non-existent. 2. A number of training programmes have been organized in the past but not aimed at targeted beneficiaries. 3. No official record of small arms collection centres in targeted communities. 4. No official record of community based action plans and projects linked to small arms collection

1. Develop a communication strategy for an effective Small Arms and Light Weapons (SALW) intervention 2. Implement at least 3 targeted sensitization and awareness campaigns based on communication strategy. 3. Training of Civil Society Organizations on resource mobilization, partnerships building, management and gender related issues. 4. Identification of arms collection centres 5. Conduct a needs assessment of community based micro projects for beneficiary communities

1. Achieved - A communication strategy for Small Arms and Light Weapons (SALW) developed. 2. Largely achieved - sensitization and awareness campaigns conducted targeting community representatives, local authorities, traditional rulers on the dangers of illegal retention and illicit circulation of small arms in their community, encouraging them to bring back their weapons in exchange of development project. Achieved - The training has led to formation of a working group on Sexual and Gender-Based Violence (SGBV) that is now working on a monitoring mechanism for documenting and sharing SGBV cases with Human Rights High Commissioner, regional authorities and international NGOs 3. Please provide information on training of CSOs or community members if this took place 4. Achieved - 4 arms collection centres identified 5. Not achieved - needs assessment of community based micro projects yet to be done

1. Develop a communication strategy for an effective Small Arms and Light Weapons (SALW) intervention 2. Implement at least 3 targeted sensitization and awareness campaigns based on communication strategy. 3. Training of Civil Society Organizations on resource mobilization, partnerships building, management and gender related issues. 4. Identification of arms collection centres 5. Conduct a needs assessment of community based micro projects for beneficiary communities

1. Achieved - A communication strategy for Small Arms and Light Weapons (SALW) developed. 2. Largely achieved - sensitization and awareness campaigns based on communication strategy successfully conducted including the critical regions of Mopti, GAO and Timbuktu. 3. Largely achieved - 25 CSOs from Bamako, Mopti, Gao, Timbuktu, and Koulikoro trained. 4. Achieved - 20 arms collection centres identified 5. Not achieved - needs assessment of community based micro projects yet to be done

description.narrative: EU Support to ECOWAS Regional Peace, Security and Stability Mandate
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1. Availability of a dedicated communication strategy aimed at addressing awareness of Small Arms and Light Weapons (SALW) 2. Extent to which training programmes have been organized for community level Civil Society organizations. 3. Number of Arms collection centres established 4. Number of community initiatives (projects) identified and implemented as a result of the arms collection exercise (collective and individual).

comment.narrative: 1. A communication strategy dedicated to addressing awareness of SALW in the selected regions is non-existent. 2. A number of training programmes have been organized in the past but not aimed at targeted beneficiaries. 3. No official record of small arms collection centres in targeted communities. 4. No official record of community based action plans and projects linked to small arms collection

1. Develop a communication strategy for an effective Small Arms and Light Weapons (SALW) intervention 2. Implement at least 3 targeted sensitization and awareness campaigns based on communication strategy. 3. Training of Civil Society Organizations on resource mobilization, partnerships building, management and gender related issues. 4. Identification of arms collection centres 5. Conduct a needs assessment of community based micro projects for beneficiary communities

1. Achieved - A communication strategy for Small Arms and Light Weapons (SALW) was updated taking into account the vision of the project. 2. Largely achieved - sensitization and awareness campaigns conducted for community representatives, local authorities, and religious leaders. Community radios in Guiglo, Man, Danane, Touba and Odienne broadcasted peace messages. 3. Achieved - a training on resource mobilization and project management was conducted for 20 participants (8 women - 12 men). A training session was also organized for 10 governors based at the western part of country’s border in Daloa. 4. Achieved - 5 arms collection centres identified 5. Largely achieved - A Community Needs Assessment has been conducted in all project implementing zones except in San Pedro region.
